caption: A photograph showing “kill markings” that indicate flying saucers on the side of a German World War II anti-aircraft gun

result.explanation: The image clearly shows a German World War II anti-aircraft gun.  The caption mentions "kill markings" indicating flying saucers, which are not visible in the provided image. Therefore, the entities related to the gun are correctly used, but the part about "kill markings" and flying saucers is incorrect.

candidates.title: Is Photo of WWII-Era German Tank That Shot Down UFOs Real?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A photograph shows UFO "kill markings" on the side of a German World War II anti-aircraft gun.
Rating:
False
About this rating
A photograph purportedly showing "kill markings" that indicate flying saucers on the side of a German World War II anti-aircraft gun has been showing up on the internet for several years, often used as proof that unidentified flying objects are a part of the historical record because a "German tank shot down a UFO":
This digitally manipulated image has been circulating since at least 2013 when it was published in the "Humor" section of the Mod DB web forum under the title "I never though the Flak 88 were THAT versatile."
While the photograph does show a German Flak 88mm anti-aircraft gun, the UFO markings were not part of the original photograph:
The original photograph was lifted from the cover of a 1943 issue of Der Adler, a Nazi propaganda magazine:
The caption identified the kill markings on the weapon as 11 planes, 40 armored tanks, and 15 anti-aircraft forts. There was no mention of UFOs.
candidates.description: A photograph purportedly showing kill markings that indicate flying saucers on a WWII-era anti-aircraft gun has been digitally manipulated.

result.explanation: The provided evidence directly contradicts the news caption. Snopes.com explicitly states that the image showing "kill markings" indicating flying saucers on a German WWII anti-aircraft gun is digitally manipulated.  The original image, from a Nazi propaganda magazine, shows kill markings for conventional targets, not UFOs. Therefore, the news caption is false.
result.supporting_points: Source 1 explicitly states that the photograph is digitally manipulated and the UFO markings were added later. The original image showed kill markings for conventional targets (planes, tanks, and anti-aircraft forts), with no mention of UFOs.

final_result.explanation: The internal validation correctly identifies the anti-aircraft gun in the image but incorrectly states that the image shows "kill markings" indicating flying saucers.  These markings are not visible. The external validation confirms this, citing Snopes.com, which states that the image was digitally manipulated; the original image shows kill markings for conventional targets, not UFOs.  Both internal and external validations agree that the caption's claim about flying saucer markings is false. The discrepancies lie in the interpretation of the image's content regarding the alleged flying saucer kill markings. The external source provides strong evidence that the caption is inaccurate by revealing the digital manipulation and the original context of the kill markings. The high confidence score reflects the strong agreement between the internal analysis identifying the gun correctly and the external validation debunking the claim about flying saucer markings.
final_result.validation_summary: Internal validation correctly identifies the gun but fails to detect the false claim of flying saucer markings. External validation confirms the caption's inaccuracy by revealing digital manipulation and the original image's context. Both analyses strongly support a conclusion that the caption is out of context.
